noun.description: A container or device in which water is boiled, having a lid, spout, and handle; a teakettle.
A small area in which demonstrators or protesters are confined by police seeking to maintain order during a demonstration.
examples: activists in the kettle were protesting at being held and resisting arrest

verb.description: (of the police) confine (a group of demonstrators or protesters) to a small area, as a method of crowd control during a demonstration.
examples: the plan was to get as close to the protest as possible without getting kettled

phrases: the new office is a rather different kettle of fish
While Gershwin, Porter and Berlin are as famous as the songs they wrote, Arlen is a different kettle of fish.
When it comes to larger mills with decent internal sorting capacities, or multi-mill operations, log sorting is a different kettle of fish.
This weblog with its proud archives is quite a different kettle of fish and a new experience for me socially.
We cannot forget what happened 50 years ago, but things are now a different kettle of fish.
origin: Old English cetel, cietel, of Germanic origin, based on Latin catillus, diminutive of catinus deep container for cooking or serving food. In Middle English the word's form was influenced by Old Norse ketill.
